sections.title: Background and Introduction
sections.tldr: The Arab Spring refers to a wave of pro-democracy uprisings that swept across several Middle Eastern and North African countries beginning in late 2010, with social media playing a pivotal role in organizing and spreading information. Researchers have increasingly applied artificial intelligence and machine learning techniques, particularly natural language processing (NLP), to analyze the vast amounts of data generated during these movements to understand information flows, detect misinformation, and examine sentiment patterns. (LLM Memory)
sections.text:
The Arab Spring represented a series of unprecedented civil uprisings and protests that began in Tunisia in December 2010 and quickly spread to Egypt, Libya, Yemen, Syria, Bahrain, and other countries across the Middle East and North Africa. These movements were characterized by calls for democracy, human rights, economic opportunities, and an end to corruption. What made the Arab Spring particularly significant was the novel role of digital technologies, especially social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube, which served as tools for organizing protests, disseminating information, and bypassing state-controlled media. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

Since these events, academic researchers have been developing increasingly sophisticated computational methods to analyze the massive datasets generated during these political movements. Natural language processing and other AI techniques have proven valuable for examining how information spread during these events, identifying propaganda campaigns, detecting misinformation, and understanding public sentiment. These technologies allow researchers to process and analyze text at scales impossible through traditional manual content analysis methods. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

The term "color revolutions" is sometimes used to describe these movements, drawing parallels to earlier pro-democracy movements in post-Soviet states that were often associated with specific colors or symbols. However, the Arab Spring movements developed their own unique characteristics and trajectories across different countries. As of 2024, with advancements in large language models and other AI technologies, researchers have gained new tools to retrospectively analyze these complex socio-political events and their information ecosystems. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

This emerging field represents an interdisciplinary approach combining political science, communication studies, computational linguistics, and data science to understand how digital media shapes political movements and how information flows during periods of social upheaval. <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">

sections.title: Role of Social Media in Arab Spring Movements
sections.tldr: Social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook played a transformative role in the Arab Spring movements by enabling citizens to organize protests, disseminate information, and bypass state-controlled media. These digital tools shifted power dynamics by allowing ordinary citizens to shape political narratives, mobilize collective action, and influence both traditional news coverage and international perceptions of the uprisings. (8 sources)
sections.text:
Social media platforms emerged as crucial catalysts during the Arab Spring movements, fundamentally altering how political protests were organized and information was shared. These digital tools enabled activists to bypass state-controlled media channels, create alternative information networks, and coordinate protest activities with unprecedented efficiency. As Horne et al. note, social media shifted power dynamics away from elites who traditionally controlled information flow to ordinary citizens and grassroots movements, particularly during the Arab Spring <Paper corpusId="267320858" paperTitle="(Horne et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This democratization of information sharing represented a significant departure from previous political movements.

The impact of social media on these uprisings was multifaceted. Platforms like Twitter and Facebook contributed to awareness-raising, recruitment of participants, mobilization of protests, and sustainability of the movements in Tunisia, Egypt, and beyond <Paper corpusId="267618300" paperTitle="(Tambari et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These digital tools amplified citizen voices and provided spaces for organizing and expressing dissent that had previously been unavailable in many of these countries <Paper corpusId="267954657" paperTitle="(Sheikh, 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. The rapid dissemination of information enabled by social media transformed isolated grievances into collective calls for political reform <Paper corpusId="268001750" paperTitle="(Kharel, 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Research has shown that social media platforms were particularly effective at shaping political discourse around the uprisings. Howard et al. found that revolutionary conversations on social networks preceded major on-the-ground revolts in Tunisia and Egypt, helping to disseminate the democratic ideas that underpinned the revolutions <Paper corpusId="273248668" paperTitle="(Torrecillas-Lacave et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have documented the crucial role of platforms like Twitter (now X) and Facebook in allowing protesters to bypass traditional media channels and shape global narratives around the protests <Paper corpusId="271428661" paperTitle="(Yaqoub et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Perhaps most significantly, social media enabled the sharing of unfiltered, user-generated content during the uprisings. Citizens, activists, and journalists shared real-time perspectives that often contradicted mainstream media narratives, leading to more nuanced international understanding of these complex movements <Paper corpusId="275966574" paperTitle="(Almakaty, 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="204825789" paperTitle="(Mavrodieva et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This aspect of social media as a "soft power" tool during the Arab Spring has continued to influence how researchers understand the relationship between digital platforms and political movements.

The Arab Spring thus represents a watershed moment in understanding how social media can facilitate collective political action, offering both historical insight and lessons for contemporary movements. These events demonstrated how digital platforms could not only connect like-minded individuals but also create sustained momentum for social and political change in environments previously dominated by tightly controlled information ecosystems.

snippets: Today's media systems are hybrid. As described by Chadwick (2017): professional-driven news cycles develop along side ordinary citizens and activist on social media. snippets: Climate change has been one of the most debated topics in the past few decades, but a number of challenges have hindered the development of robust policies and strategies by nations. At the same time, social media platforms—such as Instagram, Twitter, and Facebook—have given the opportunity for the general public to share opinions and engage with the issue of climate change like never before. This phenomenon is considered to be a new form of soft power which can provide input into the discussion and possibly affect the current international political mechanisms. The present paper aims to (1) define the forms and characteristics of social media as a soft power method, (2) analyze its influence on the awareness of societies, and (3) assess if increased public awareness could influence the official political and policy processes. In order to assess if social media has influence on people’s relative awareness, we have focused on analyzing the links between a few highly visible climate change related events and the trends in people’s searches on the Internet in connection to those events. The study finds that even though it is difficult to assess the effects of social media as a soft power tool with certainty, there are visible links between social media and changing public perceptions, with the possibility of public opinion influencing political decision-making.

sections.title: NLP and AI Techniques for Analyzing Arab Spring Content
sections.tldr: Researchers have employed various natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning techniques to analyze the vast amounts of text data generated during the Arab Spring movements. These techniques include sentiment analysis, topic modeling, text classification, and the use of large language models to process news articles, social media content, and other textual data related to political unrest and social movements. (9 sources)
sections.text:
Natural language processing (NLP) and artificial intelligence techniques have emerged as crucial tools for analyzing the enormous volumes of textual data generated during the Arab Spring movements. These computational methods have enabled researchers to extract meaningful insights from news articles, social media posts, and other text sources at unprecedented scales. As social media platforms played a pivotal role in these movements, NLP techniques have been particularly valuable for understanding how information spread and influenced public opinion during these political upheavals.

Sentiment analysis stands out as one of the most widely applied NLP techniques in studying the Arab Spring. This approach allows researchers to classify text into positive, negative, or neutral sentiments, providing insights into public opinions toward political candidates, parties, and key issues <Paper corpusId="273654880" paperTitle="(Chercheur et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Unlike traditional polling methods, which can be expensive and difficult to implement in certain contexts, sentiment analysis leverages publicly available data to create real-time understanding of political sentiment, making it especially valuable in regions with limited polling data <Paper corpusId="273654880" paperTitle="(Chercheur et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="43980624" paperTitle="(Jaidka et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

Topic modeling, an unsupervised machine learning technique, has been extensively used to discover prevalent themes in collections of documents related to political movements <Paper corpusId="271755037" paperTitle="(Buryakov et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. For instance, researchers have applied topic modeling to examine millions of social media posts about political events, identifying predominant topics and their associations with particular political positions <Paper corpusId="271755037" paperTitle="(Buryakov et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach helps researchers understand the key concerns and narratives that shaped public discourse during the Arab Spring.

Text classification represents another important NLP application in analyzing Arab Spring content. Social media researchers routinely employ classification techniques to categorize large quantities of text data, allowing them to identify and analyze specific types of content, such as hate speech, public attitudes, or news credibility <Paper corpusId="272689332" paperTitle="(Pangakis et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. More recently, researchers have begun deploying generative large language models (LLMs) for annotation tasks, enhancing the efficiency and scalability of text analysis <Paper corpusId="272689332" paperTitle="(Pangakis et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

NLP tools have proven particularly valuable in crisis monitoring during political unrest. Researchers have developed specialized corpora, such as Kawarith—a collection of Arabic tweets representing disaster events—to train and test NLP models for crisis-related content analysis <Paper corpusId="268926665" paperTitle="(Moussa et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Various machine learning approaches, including BERT models, have been employed to classify crisis-related posts, detect relevant events, and filter out irrelevant information <Paper corpusId="268926665" paperTitle="(Moussa et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The application of these technologies extends beyond academic research to practical challenges like predicting country instability. Researchers have leveraged AI and machine learning tools to analyze massive volumes of qualitative data from television, print, digital, and social media sources to make sense of complex socio-political dynamics and enhance predictive accuracy <Paper corpusId="273962822" paperTitle="(Zebrowski et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach recognizes the interconnectedness of global economies and social networks in shaping political movements.

Urban planning scholars have also adopted NLP techniques to extract valuable insights from social media content related to the Arab Spring, including sentiment analysis, topic modeling, and named entity recognition <Paper corpusId="269857939" paperTitle="(Bibri et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These methods help researchers understand public opinions and identify trends across diverse temporal and spatial contexts, informing decision-making processes in urban planning and design <Paper corpusId="269857939" paperTitle="(Bibri et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

In the financial domain, NLP has been applied to analyze textual data from financial reports, news articles, and social media content during periods of political unrest, providing insights into market sentiment, investor behavior, and economic trends <Paper corpusId="267311958" paperTitle="(Kanaparthi, 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Advanced NLP techniques such as sentiment analysis and topic modeling have enabled the development of sophisticated AI models that effectively process and analyze textual information in finance <Paper corpusId="267311958" paperTitle="(Kanaparthi, 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="238803253" paperTitle="(Khalil et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: In the evolving landscape of political forecasting, traditional methods such as opinion polls and voter surveys are often limited by sample size, time delays, and response biases (Ansu-Kyeremeh, 1999). With the rapid digitalization of news and the proliferation of online media, public sentiment, as reflected in news articles, has emerged as a valuable indicator of political climate [2]. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, particularly sentiment analysis, offers a modern approach to gauge public opinion through media coverage. Sentiment analysis classifies text into sentiments-positive, negative, or neutral-allowing researchers to discern the tone of media articles discussing political candidates and key issues [3]. This technology has been applied to various domains, including marketing, finance, and politics, providing a predictive edge in decisionmaking processes (Lotfi et al., 2021). Recent elections in several democratic countries have witnessed increasing interest in using AIdriven sentiment analysis for election forecasting [5]. In contrast to traditional polling, which can be cost-prohibitive and difficult to implement in certain contexts, AI-based sentiment analysis leverages publicly available data, such as news articles and social media posts, to create a real-time understanding of political sentiment (Jaidka et al., 2019). By processing and analyzing large volumes of text, AI can extract patterns of support, opposition, or neutrality toward political candidates and parties. These patterns can then be used to predict election outcomes, making sentiment analysis a promising tool for political forecasters, especially in regions with limited or unreliable polling data [7].

paper.title: Leveraging AI and Sentiment Analysis for Forecasting Election Outcomes in Mauritius

snippets: ABSTRACT This study introduces and evaluates the robustness of different volumetric, sentiment, and social network approaches to predict the elections in three Asian countries – Malaysia, India, and Pakistan from Twitter posts. We find that predictive power of social media performs well for India and Pakistan but is not effective for Malaysia. Overall, we find that it is useful to consider the recency of Twitter posts while using it to predict a real outcome, such as an election result. Sentiment information mined using machine learning models was the most accurate predictor of election outcomes. Social network information is stable despite sudden surges in political discussions, for e.g. around elections-related news events. Methods combining sentiment and volume information, or sentiment and social network information, are effective at predicting smaller vote shares, for e.g. vote shares in the case of independent candidates and regional parties. We conclude with a detailed discussion on the caveats of social media analysis for predicting real-world outcomes and recommendations for future work.

snippets: This study tries to unravel the stock market prediction puzzle using the textual analytic with the help of natural language processing (NLP) techniques and Deep-learning recurrent model called long short term memory (LSTM). Instead of using count-based traditional sentiment index methods, the study uses its own sum and relevance based sentiment index mechanism. Hourly price data has been used in this research as daily data is too late and minutes data is too early for getting the exclusive effect of sentiments. Normally, hourly data is extremely costly and difficult to manage and analyze. Hourly data has been rarely used in similar kinds of researches. To built sentiment index, text analytic information has been parsed and analyzed, textual information that is relevant to selected stocks has been collected, aggregated, categorized, and refined with NLP and eventually converted scientifically into hourly sentiment index. News analytic sources include mainstream media, print media, social media, news feeds, blogs, investors’ advisory portals, experts’ opinions, brokers updates, web-based information, company’ internal news and public announcements regarding policies and reforms. The results of the study indicate that sentiments significantly influence the direction of stocks, on average after 3–4 h. Top ten companies from High-tech, financial, medical, automobile sectors are selected, and six LSTM models, three for using text-analytic and other without analytic are used. Every model includes 1, 3, and 6 h steps back. For all sectors, a 6-hour steps based model outperforms the other models due to LSTM specialty of keeping long term memory. Collective accuracy of textual analytic models is way higher relative to non-textual analytic models.

sections.title: Propaganda and Misinformation Detection
sections.tldr: Researchers have developed specialized methods to detect propaganda and misinformation in Arabic content across social media and news platforms, addressing unique challenges posed by the language's complex morphology and diverse dialects. These efforts include creating annotated datasets, applying machine learning techniques, and leveraging large language models to identify propaganda techniques and misinformation in the context of regional events like the Arab Spring and ongoing conflicts. (13 sources)
sections.text:
The proliferation of propaganda and misinformation across digital platforms during and after the Arab Spring has prompted significant research into automated detection methods. This research addresses unique challenges in Arabic content analysis, where the language's complexity creates additional obstacles for detection systems. The Arabic language presents several distinct challenges for propaganda and misinformation detection, including its rich vocabulary and the presence of various dialects used across different Arab countries and regions. Social media users typically communicate using both Modern Standard Arabic (MSA), the formal language, and Dialectal Arabic (DA), the informal language used in daily communication, with the latter being more common online <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="157063678" paperTitle="(AL-Saif et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

The aftermath of the Arab Spring and Syrian crisis saw a significant increase in rumors and false information circulating online, highlighting the need for robust detection systems <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="26631757" paperTitle="(Zaatari et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. To address this challenge, researchers have developed specialized Arabic corpora for credibility classification, recognizing the lack of such resources despite the growing popularity of blogs and microblogs in the Arab world <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="26631757" paperTitle="(Zaatari et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. These efforts aim to filter out non-credible information using machine learning approaches that require sufficiently large and accurate training data.

Recent advances in propaganda detection for Arabic content include the development of optimized systems leveraging transformer-based language models such as AraBERT with neural network classifiers for sequence tagging <Paper corpusId="270870581" paperTitle="(Abir et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Researchers have proposed robust preprocessing pipelines specifically for Arabic, addressing unique challenges such as Unicode inconsistencies, misaligned annotations, and user-mention normalization. These pipelines aim to improve the detection of propagandistic techniques in Arabic texts, which is crucial for maintaining information integrity <Paper corpusId="270870581" paperTitle="(Abir et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The detection of political bias in social media content has also received attention, with researchers identifying bias in user-generated content and surveying sentiment analysis techniques <Paper corpusId="271432238" paperTitle="(Zaghouani et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have advanced beyond examining lexical bias (captured by linguistic attributes like word choice and syntax) to address informational bias—factual content that can nevertheless be deployed to sway reader opinion <Paper corpusId="271432238" paperTitle="(Zaghouani et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="202537179" paperTitle="(Fan et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This distinction is particularly important in the context of the Arab Spring, where the credibility of information shared on social media platforms significantly influenced public perception and participation in political movements.

Several initiatives have specifically focused on Arabic propaganda detection, addressing the language gap in research that previously concentrated primarily on English content. The WANLP 2022 workshop, for instance, organized a shared task for detecting propaganda techniques in Arabic tweets through multilabel classification, attracting 63 participating teams <Paper corpusId="271769411" paperTitle="(Haouhat et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="253708388" paperTitle="(Alam et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Researchers have also explored the potential of large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4 to function as both general and expert annotators for identifying and labeling propagandistic spans within Arabic textual content <Paper corpusId="271769411" paperTitle="(Haouhat et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The ongoing Palestinian-Israeli conflict illustrates how social media platforms can be plagued with bias and propaganda despite the abundance of information available online. Traditional media bias and propaganda have accumulated over decades, and social networks now echo the same narratives and talking points from global media <Paper corpusId="271769819" paperTitle="(Helal et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Researchers have applied various methodologies to detect bias and propaganda in news and social media posts, including sentiment analysis using Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Machine Learning (ML) techniques <Paper corpusId="271769819" paperTitle="(Helal et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="5171778" paperTitle="(Park et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

The impact of social communications on public opinion, cultural stereotypes, and user behavior during events like wars, revolutions, and pandemics has been studied to understand how these communications influence interactions among social groups and institutions <Paper corpusId="272951331" paperTitle="(Valle-Cruz et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Examinations of media coverage, particularly by major outlets like the BBC, have revealed potential biases in the representation of events such as the Syrian civil conflict, highlighting the importance of scrutinizing information quality in both traditional and social media during political upheavals <Paper corpusId="272951331" paperTitle="(Valle-Cruz et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The proliferation of propaganda on online platforms has spurred a significant surge in research aimed at automatically identifying propagandistic content across textual, visual, and multimodal formats <Paper corpusId="271038699" paperTitle="(Hasanain et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. While earlier efforts focused primarily on English content, there is increasing interest in other languages, including Arabic <Paper corpusId="271038699" paperTitle="(Hasanain et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="202788575" paperTitle="(Martino et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Researchers have moved beyond document-level propaganda detection to performing fine-grained analysis of texts by identifying specific fragments containing propaganda techniques and classifying them by type <Paper corpusId="271038699" paperTitle="(Hasanain et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="202788575" paperTitle="(Martino et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach provides greater explainability and addresses the limitations of systems trained on noisy gold labels from propagandistic news outlets.

snippets: Rumors and false information have also proliferated in politics, as was the case during the Arab Spring and the Syrian crisis (Zaatari et al., 2016). The Arabic language is considered one of the most commonly spoken languages in the world, and an essential language for Muslims worldwide, who numbered about 1.8 billion in 2015 and are expected to increase to three billion in 2060, according to the Pew Research Center [8]. The Arabic language presents various challenges. First, there are different dialects used in different Arab countries, as well as from regions in the same country. The language also has a rich vocabulary that leads to the occurrence of misleading information from different dialects, making it more difficult for the system to detect (Alqurashi et al., 2021). In social media, the complexity of understanding the Arabic language is increased because users on social media, such as Twitter, use two forms of the language: Modern Standard Arabic (MSA), which is the formal language, and Dialect Arabic (DA), which is informal, used in daily communication between users, and is more common than MSA (AL-Saif et al., 2019).

snippets: With the current increase in the number of online users, there has been a concomitant increase in the amount of data shared online. Techniques for discovering knowledge from these data can provide us with valuable information when it comes to detecting different problems, including violence. Violence is one of the significant problems humanity has faced in recent years all over the world, and this is especially a problem in Arabic countries. To address this issue, this research focuses on detecting violence-related tweets to help in solving this problem. Text mining is an important technique that can be used to find and predict information from text. In this study, a text classification model is built for detecting violence in Arabic dialects on Twitter using different feature-reduction approaches. The experiment comprises bagging, K-nearest neighbors (KNN), and Bayesian boosting using different extraction features, namely, root-based stemming, light stemming, and n-grams. In addition, the study used the following feature-reduction techniques: support vector machine (SVM), Chi-squared (CHI), the Gini index, correlation, rules, information gain (IG), deviation, symmetrical uncertainty, and the IG ratio. The experiment showed that the bagging with tri-gram approach has the highest accuracy at 86.61%, and a combination of IG with SVM from reduction features registers an accuracy of 90.59%.

snippets: The increasing prevalence of political bias in news media calls for greater public awareness of it, as well as robust methods for its detection. While prior work in NLP has primarily focused on the lexical bias captured by linguistic attributes such as word choice and syntax, other types of bias stem from the actual content selected for inclusion in the text. In this work, we investigate the effects of informational bias: factual content that can nevertheless be deployed to sway reader opinion. We first produce a new dataset, BASIL, of 300 news articles annotated with 1,727 bias spans and find evidence that informational bias appears in news articles more frequently than lexical bias. We further study our annotations to observe how informational bias surfaces in news articles by different media outlets. Lastly, a baseline model for informational bias prediction is presented by fine-tuning BERT on our labeled data, indicating the challenges of the task and future directions.

snippets: Propaganda is defined as an expression of opinion or action by individuals or groups deliberately designed to influence opinions or actions of other individuals or groups with reference to predetermined ends and this is achieved by means of well-defined rhetorical and psychological devices. Currently, propaganda (or persuasion) techniques have been commonly used on social media to manipulate or mislead social media users. Automatic detection of propaganda techniques from textual, visual, or multimodal content has been studied recently, however, major of such efforts are focused on English language content. In this paper, we propose a shared task on detecting propaganda techniques for Arabic textual content. We have done a pilot annotation of 200 Arabic tweets, which we plan to extend to 2,000 tweets, covering diverse topics. We hope that the shared task will help in building a community for Arabic propaganda detection. The dataset will be made publicly available, which can help in future studies.

snippets: Propaganda aims at influencing people’s mindset with the purpose of advancing a specific agenda. Previous work has addressed propaganda detection at document level, typically labelling all articles from a propagandistic news outlet as propaganda. Such noisy gold labels inevitably affect the quality of any learning system trained on them. A further issue with most existing systems is the lack of explainability. To overcome these limitations, we propose a novel task: performing fine-grained analysis of texts by detecting all fragments that contain propaganda techniques as well as their type. In particular, we create a corpus of news articles manually annotated at fragment level with eighteen propaganda techniques and propose a suitable evaluation measure. We further design a novel multi-granularity neural network, and we show that it outperforms several strong BERT-based baselines.

sections.title: Sentiment Analysis Applications
sections.tldr: Sentiment analysis has emerged as a crucial tool for monitoring public opinion during political events like the Arab Spring, enabling researchers to classify social media content into positive, negative, or neutral sentiments. This approach has proven particularly valuable for predicting political outcomes, detecting early warning signs of social unrest, and tracking changing public attitudes toward government actions in real-time. (6 sources)
sections.text:
Sentiment analysis has evolved into a powerful application of natural language processing for understanding public opinion during political movements like the Arab Spring. Traditional methods of gauging public sentiment, such as opinion polls and voter surveys, often suffer from limitations including small sample sizes, time delays, and response biases. The digitalization of news and the proliferation of online media have created opportunities to analyze public sentiment through media coverage using AI and NLP techniques <Paper corpusId="273654880" paperTitle="(Chercheur et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Sentiment analysis classifies text into positive, negative, or neutral categories, enabling researchers to discern the tone of media articles discussing political candidates, parties, and key issues <Paper corpusId="273654880" paperTitle="(Chercheur et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

One of the most valuable applications of sentiment analysis is political forecasting and election prediction. Unlike traditional polling, which can be expensive and challenging to implement in certain contexts, AI-based sentiment analysis leverages publicly available data such as news articles and social media posts to create real-time understanding of political sentiment <Paper corpusId="273654880" paperTitle="(Chercheur et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="43980624" paperTitle="(Jaidka et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Research has demonstrated that sentiment information extracted using machine learning models can be an accurate predictor of election outcomes, particularly in Asian countries like India and Pakistan <Paper corpusId="43980624" paperTitle="(Jaidka et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Combined approaches that integrate sentiment with volume information or social network data have proven especially effective at predicting smaller vote shares, such as those for independent candidates and regional parties <Paper corpusId="43980624" paperTitle="(Jaidka et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

Perhaps most critically, sentiment analysis serves as an early warning system for social unrest. Emotional sentiment can function as an indicator of impending chaos, allowing authorities to intervene before tensions escalate, as witnessed during events like the Arab Spring <Paper corpusId="276132381" paperTitle="(Zaabar et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261470218" paperTitle="(Arora et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. By applying NLP techniques to social media content, researchers can detect shifts in emotional tone or intensity across populations, identifying concerning patterns of anger, fear, or frustration that might presage larger social threats <Paper corpusId="276132381" paperTitle="(Zaabar et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="261470218" paperTitle="(Arora et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. The high-volume application of sentiment analysis to user-generated content has proven particularly useful for monitoring indicators of social instability, disinformation campaigns, and other factors that may threaten national security <Paper corpusId="276132381" paperTitle="(Zaabar et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

Sentiment analysis and machine learning have also been deployed to track public attitudes toward government interventions, misinformation campaigns, and election outcomes <Paper corpusId="276487652" paperTitle="(Nedungadi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. This application highlights AI's role in facilitating real-time information dissemination and shaping our understanding of public opinion during political movements <Paper corpusId="276487652" paperTitle="(Nedungadi et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. The integration of sentiment analysis into broader AI frameworks has enabled more sophisticated modeling of investor decision-making and market movements during periods of political uncertainty, overcoming traditional assumptions about market efficiency by capturing the behavior of agents who might trade based on rumors or false information <Paper corpusId="245753310" paperTitle="(Lotfi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The development of advanced AI algorithms specifically tailored for sentiment analysis during political movements has demonstrated significant advantages over classical statistical models, which often rely on assumptions that don't hold in real-world scenarios like the Arab Spring <Paper corpusId="245753310" paperTitle="(Lotfi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. These more sophisticated approaches can process and analyze large volumes of text to extract patterns of support, opposition, or neutrality toward political actors and movements, making sentiment analysis an increasingly valuable tool for researchers studying complex sociopolitical events, especially in regions with limited or unreliable polling data <Paper corpusId="273654880" paperTitle="(Chercheur et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: In the evolving landscape of political forecasting, traditional methods such as opinion polls and voter surveys are often limited by sample size, time delays, and response biases (Ansu-Kyeremeh, 1999). With the rapid digitalization of news and the proliferation of online media, public sentiment, as reflected in news articles, has emerged as a valuable indicator of political climate [2]. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, particularly sentiment analysis, offers a modern approach to gauge public opinion through media coverage. Sentiment analysis classifies text into sentiments-positive, negative, or neutral-allowing researchers to discern the tone of media articles discussing political candidates and key issues [3]. This technology has been applied to various domains, including marketing, finance, and politics, providing a predictive edge in decisionmaking processes (Lotfi et al., 2021). Recent elections in several democratic countries have witnessed increasing interest in using AIdriven sentiment analysis for election forecasting [5]. In contrast to traditional polling, which can be cost-prohibitive and difficult to implement in certain contexts, AI-based sentiment analysis leverages publicly available data, such as news articles and social media posts, to create a real-time understanding of political sentiment (Jaidka et al., 2019). By processing and analyzing large volumes of text, AI can extract patterns of support, opposition, or neutrality toward political candidates and parties. These patterns can then be used to predict election outcomes, making sentiment analysis a promising tool for political forecasters, especially in regions with limited or unreliable polling data [7].

paper.title: Leveraging AI and Sentiment Analysis for Forecasting Election Outcomes in Mauritius

snippets: ABSTRACT This study introduces and evaluates the robustness of different volumetric, sentiment, and social network approaches to predict the elections in three Asian countries – Malaysia, India, and Pakistan from Twitter posts. We find that predictive power of social media performs well for India and Pakistan but is not effective for Malaysia. Overall, we find that it is useful to consider the recency of Twitter posts while using it to predict a real outcome, such as an election result. Sentiment information mined using machine learning models was the most accurate predictor of election outcomes. Social network information is stable despite sudden surges in political discussions, for e.g. around elections-related news events. Methods combining sentiment and volume information, or sentiment and social network information, are effective at predicting smaller vote shares, for e.g. vote shares in the case of independent candidates and regional parties. We conclude with a detailed discussion on the caveats of social media analysis for predicting real-world outcomes and recommendations for future work.

snippets: In recent years, groups of cyber criminals/hackers have carried out cyber-attacks using various tactics with the goal of destabilizing web services in a specific context for which they are motivated. Predicting these attacks is a critical task that assists in determining what actions should be taken to mitigate the effects of such attacks and to prevent them in the future. Although there are programs to detect security concerns on the internet, there is currently no system that can anticipate or foretell whether the attacks will be successful. This research aims to develop sustainable strategies to reduce threats, vulnerability, and data manipulation of chatbots, consequently improving cyber security. To achieve this goal, we develop a conversational chatbot, an application that uses artificial intelligence (AI) to communicate, and deploy it on social media sites (e.g., Twitter) for cyber security purposes. Chatbots have the capacity to consume large amounts of information and give an appropriate response in an efficient and timely manner, thus rendering them useful in predicting threats emanating from social media. The research utilizes sentiment analysis strategy by employing chatbots on Twitter (and analyzing Twitter data) for predicting future threats and cyber-attacks. The strategy is based on a daily collection of tweets from two types of users: those who use the platform to voice their opinions on important and relevant subjects, and those who use it to share information on cyber security attacks. The research provides tools and strategies for developing chatbots that can be used for assessing cyber threats on social media through sentiment analysis leading to a global sustainable development of businesses. Future research may utilize and improvise on the tools and strategies suggested in our research to strengthen the knowledge domain of chatbots, cyber security, and social media.

sections.title: Challenges in Arabic NLP
sections.tldr: Arabic natural language processing faces unique challenges due to the language's rich morphology, diverse dialects, and the coexistence of formal Modern Standard Arabic (MSA) and informal Dialectal Arabic (DA) in social media communications. These linguistic complexities create significant obstacles for developing effective NLP tools to analyze the Arab Spring and related events, particularly in tasks like propaganda detection, misinformation identification, and sentiment analysis. (9 sources)
sections.text:
Arabic presents distinctive challenges for natural language processing researchers studying content related to the Arab Spring and subsequent political movements. The language's complexity is multifaceted, beginning with its rich vocabulary and morphological structure that complicate automated text analysis <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Perhaps most significantly, Arabic exists in multiple forms used across different contexts: Modern Standard Arabic (MSA), which serves as the formal language, and Dialectal Arabic (DA), which represents the informal language used in everyday communication. On social media platforms—critical sources for Arab Spring research—users typically employ both forms, with the informal DA being more prevalent than MSA <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="157063678" paperTitle="(AL-Saif et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

The dialectal variation within Arabic presents a substantial obstacle for NLP systems. Different dialects are used across Arab countries and even across regions within the same country, creating significant linguistic diversity <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This variation can lead to misleading information as systems struggle to account for dialectal differences in vocabulary, syntax, and semantics <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="231603127" paperTitle="(Alqurashi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. For research analyzing Arab Spring content, these dialectal variations pose a particular challenge as they can confound systems attempting to detect subtle propagandistic messaging or misinformation.

The aftermath of the Arab Spring and Syrian crisis saw a proliferation of rumors and false information online, highlighting the urgent need for credibility classification systems specifically designed for Arabic content <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="26631757" paperTitle="(Zaatari et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. While effective machine learning approaches require large, accurate training datasets, there has been a notable lack of public Arabic corpora for tasks like credibility classification, despite the growing popularity of blogs and microblogs in the Arab world <Paper corpusId="267503979" paperTitle="(Alotaibi et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="26631757" paperTitle="(Zaatari et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. This data scarcity represents a significant challenge for research in this domain.

In the specific area of propaganda detection, researchers face additional challenges when working with Arabic content. While propaganda detection has received considerable attention for English language content, Arabic has historically received less focus despite its importance <Paper corpusId="271769411" paperTitle="(Haouhat et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="253708388" paperTitle="(Alam et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Efforts to bridge this language gap include the creation of specialized datasets, such as one containing 16 million Arabic tweets with a subset labeled for propaganda <Paper corpusId="271769411" paperTitle="(Haouhat et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. However, existing datasets often have limitations in terms of topic coverage or regional focus, necessitating generalization to diverse topics and regions across the Arab world <Paper corpusId="271769411" paperTitle="(Haouhat et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The increasing reliance on social media for news consumption among Arab youth—with approximately 79% obtaining news from social media—underscores the importance of focusing on Arabic content for fake news detection <Paper corpusId="273743203" paperTitle="(Mostafa et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. The unique linguistic and cultural nuances inherent in Arabic social media content require specialized approaches for effective analysis <Paper corpusId="273743203" paperTitle="(Mostafa et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. While substantial research has focused on machine learning methodologies for fake news detection on social media platforms, many studies primarily address English datasets, creating a research gap for Arabic content <Paper corpusId="273743203" paperTitle="(Mostafa et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="234785728" paperTitle="(Al-Yahya et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="246780500" paperTitle="(Himdi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent efforts have attempted to address these challenges by developing Arabic natural language processing tools specifically designed for tasks like fake news detection and textual feature extraction <Paper corpusId="246780500" paperTitle="(Himdi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, researchers have explored the use of transformer-based language models for Arabic fake news detection, demonstrating performance improvements compared to neural network-based solutions <Paper corpusId="234785728" paperTitle="(Al-Yahya et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Despite these advances, significant challenges remain in developing comprehensive NLP systems capable of effectively analyzing the complex linguistic landscape of Arabic political and social media content.

snippets: Rumors and false information have also proliferated in politics, as was the case during the Arab Spring and the Syrian crisis (Zaatari et al., 2016). The Arabic language is considered one of the most commonly spoken languages in the world, and an essential language for Muslims worldwide, who numbered about 1.8 billion in 2015 and are expected to increase to three billion in 2060, according to the Pew Research Center [8]. The Arabic language presents various challenges. First, there are different dialects used in different Arab countries, as well as from regions in the same country. The language also has a rich vocabulary that leads to the occurrence of misleading information from different dialects, making it more difficult for the system to detect (Alqurashi et al., 2021). In social media, the complexity of understanding the Arabic language is increased because users on social media, such as Twitter, use two forms of the language: Modern Standard Arabic (MSA), which is the formal language, and Dialect Arabic (DA), which is informal, used in daily communication between users, and is more common than MSA (AL-Saif et al., 2019).

snippets: With the current increase in the number of online users, there has been a concomitant increase in the amount of data shared online. Techniques for discovering knowledge from these data can provide us with valuable information when it comes to detecting different problems, including violence. Violence is one of the significant problems humanity has faced in recent years all over the world, and this is especially a problem in Arabic countries. To address this issue, this research focuses on detecting violence-related tweets to help in solving this problem. Text mining is an important technique that can be used to find and predict information from text. In this study, a text classification model is built for detecting violence in Arabic dialects on Twitter using different feature-reduction approaches. The experiment comprises bagging, K-nearest neighbors (KNN), and Bayesian boosting using different extraction features, namely, root-based stemming, light stemming, and n-grams. In addition, the study used the following feature-reduction techniques: support vector machine (SVM), Chi-squared (CHI), the Gini index, correlation, rules, information gain (IG), deviation, symmetrical uncertainty, and the IG ratio. The experiment showed that the bagging with tri-gram approach has the highest accuracy at 86.61%, and a combination of IG with SVM from reduction features registers an accuracy of 90.59%.

snippets: Fake news detection (FND) involves predicting the likelihood that a particular news article (news report, editorial, expose, etc.) is intentionally deceptive. Arabic FND started to receive more attention in the last decade, and many detection approaches demonstrated some ability to detect fake news on multiple datasets. However, most existing approaches do not consider recent advances in natural language processing, i.e., the use of neural networks and transformers. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative study of neural network and transformer-based language models used for Arabic FND. We examine the use of neural networks and transformer-based language models for Arabic FND and show their performance compared to each other. We also conduct an extensive analysis of the possible reasons for the difference in performance results obtained by different approaches. The results demonstrate that transformer-based models outperform the neural network-based solutions, which led to an increase in the F1 score from 0.83 (best neural network-based model, GRU) to 0.95 (best transformer-based model, QARiB), and it boosted the accuracy by 16% compared to the best in neural network-based solutions. Finally, we highlight the main gaps in Arabic FND research and suggest future research directions.

snippets: Over the years, social media has had a considerable impact on the way we share information and send messages. With this comes the problem of the rapid distribution of fake news which can have negative impacts on both individuals and society. Given the potential negative influence, detecting unmonitored ‘fake news’ has become a critical issue in mainstream media. While there are recent studies that built machine learning models that detect fake news in several languages, lack of studies in detecting fake news in the Arabic language is scare. Hence, in this paper, we study the issue of fake news detection in the Arabic language based on textual analysis. In an attempt to address the challenges of authenticating news, we introduce a supervised machine learning model that classifies Arabic news articles based on their context’s credibility. We also introduce the first dataset of Arabic fake news articles composed through crowdsourcing. Subsequently, to extract textual features from the articles, we create a unique approach of forming Arabic lexical wordlists and design an Arabic Natural Language Processing tool to perform textual features extraction. The findings of this study promises great results and outperformed human performance in the same task.

sections.tldr: Future research on the Arab Spring should focus on developing more sophisticated NLP tools for Arabic language processing, creating multilingual datasets, and integrating multimodal analysis approaches that combine text with visual content. Researchers should also explore cross-platform information flow analysis, develop early warning systems for social unrest, and address ethical challenges in analyzing political content. (5 sources)

Around 79% of Arab youth obtain their news from social media, showing a significant increase from previous years. This substantial user base underscores the importance of focusing on Arabic tweets for fake news detection. Moreover, the linguistic and cultural nuances inherent in Arabic tweets present unique challenges that require specialized approaches for effective fake news detection.

Over the past years, a considerable body of research has focused on the application of machine learning methodologies to develop automated models aimed at detecting fake news on social media platforms. Recent surveys highlight various machine learning techniques (Mishra, Shukla & Agarwal, 2022;Alghamdi, Luo & Lin, 2024), with some focusing on textual models for news content (Al-Yahya et al., 2021;Himdi et al., 2022;Capuano et al., 2023), while others explore multimodal approaches that incorporate both textual and multimedia features (Comito, Caroprese & Zumpano, 2023;Tufchi, Yadav & Ahmed, 2023). However, many of these studies primarily focus on English datasets, leaving a gap in research on other languages.

snippets: Fake news detection (FND) involves predicting the likelihood that a particular news article (news report, editorial, expose, etc.) is intentionally deceptive. Arabic FND started to receive more attention in the last decade, and many detection approaches demonstrated some ability to detect fake news on multiple datasets. However, most existing approaches do not consider recent advances in natural language processing, i.e., the use of neural networks and transformers. This paper presents a comprehensive comparative study of neural network and transformer-based language models used for Arabic FND. We examine the use of neural networks and transformer-based language models for Arabic FND and show their performance compared to each other. We also conduct an extensive analysis of the possible reasons for the difference in performance results obtained by different approaches. The results demonstrate that transformer-based models outperform the neural network-based solutions, which led to an increase in the F1 score from 0.83 (best neural network-based model, GRU) to 0.95 (best transformer-based model, QARiB), and it boosted the accuracy by 16% compared to the best in neural network-based solutions. Finally, we highlight the main gaps in Arabic FND research and suggest future research directions.

snippets: The proliferation of fake news on social media platforms poses significant challenges to society and individuals, leading to negative impacts. As the tactics employed by purveyors of fake news continue to evolve, there is an urgent need for automatic fake news detection (FND) to mitigate its adverse social consequences. Machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques have emerged as promising approaches for characterising and identifying fake news content. This paper presents an extensive review of previous studies aiming to understand and combat the dissemination of fake news. The review begins by exploring the definitions of fake news proposed in the literature and delves into related terms and psychological and scientific theories that shed light on why people believe and disseminate fake news. Subsequently, advanced ML and DL techniques for FND are dicussed in detail, focusing on three main feature categories: content-based, context-based, and hybrid-based features. Additionally, the review summarises the characteristics of fake news, commonly used datasets, and the methodologies employed in existing studies. Furthermore, the review identifies the challenges current FND studies encounter and highlights areas that require further investigation in future research. By offering a comprehensive overview of the field, this survey aims to serve as a guide for researchers working on FND, providing valuable insights for developing effective FND mechanisms in the era of technological advancements.
